Dyno Nobel Inc, St. Helens Plant



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONCE POLICIES



The Dyno Nobel- St. Helens facility has been in operation since 1966.  Since the beginning the employees and management have had accident prevention and training programs in place for the safety of the general public and employees of the facility.  These programs include detailed operator training, operating instructions, maintenance procedures, active employee safety committees, safety inspections and emergency procedures.  The facility is also regulated by the OSHA Process Safety Management system. In the event that an accidential release were to occur, Dyno Nobel Inc. has established an Integrated Contingency Plan with the input of the Columbia River Fire and Rescue to ensure that the effects of a release would be minimized. 





DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE & REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Dyno Nobel Inc. St Helens Facility produces nitrogen-based fertilizers. Seventy full time employees operate and manage the site, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year. During normal operation, the facility operates four inter-connected plants that produce ammonia, urea, nitric acid, and ammonium nitrate. From these base commodities, the facility is able to produce and sell the following products:

 

?    Anhydrous Ammonia

?    30% Ammonium Hydroxide

?    19% Ammonium Hydroxide

?    40% Urea Solutions

?    32.5% Urea Solutions

?    Urea Prill

?    Ultra Low Biuret Urea Pellets

?    86% Ammonium Nitrate Solutions

?    32% Urea Ammonium Nitrate Solutions



These products are manufactured from natural gas, air and water.  For RMP planning purposes the enitre site is considered the stationary source. The regulated substances handled on site in quantities larger than threshold amounts are Anhydrous Ammonia and 30% Aqua Ammonia.  There are two active 625 ton Anhydrous Ammonia storage spheres on site and a 30% Aqua Ammonia storage tank with the capacity of 95,000 ga

llons.





GENERAL ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION



Many different tools and methodolgies are used to prevent accidential releases from occurring at the St. Helens facility. These include but are not limited to, the use of Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices for design changes or additions, an uninterrupted power supply for the computer system used for instrumentation and controls, redundant process alarms, remotely operated isolation valves, automatic shutdown systems, duplicate pumps and compressors, atmospheric pressure relief devices, a back-up instrument air compressor, secondary containment and curbing, and fire monitors  which are strategically located around the process.



In addition a robust Process Safety Management program is in place at the facility. Elements of the Process Safety Management program include updating and maintaining process safety information and operating procedures, analyzing process hazards, development and maintenance of a training and mechanical integrity program, maintaining a process for initiating and managing change including a process for pre-startup safety review, compliance audits, incident investigation, employee participation, hot work permit, contractor safety, and emergency planning and response.  



In terms of employee participation, the plant has a strong safety culture in which all members of the team are able to voice their opinions and concerns without negative consequence. It is important to management that all groups are represented when a committee, task force, project team, or any other group meets to discuss plant operations, projects, hazards, temporary operations, etc. It is important that both salaried and hourly representatives be present as much as practicable and applicable. Examples of outlets for employee participation (cross-functional teams) at the St. Helens Plant include, but are not limited to:

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



There have been no releases of anhydrous ammonia that meet the EPA release criteria definition over the last five years.



AQUA AMMONIA >20%

There have been no releases of aqua ammonia >20% that meet the EPA release criteria definition over the last five years.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



The Dyno Nobel- St. Helens Plant is transitioning to an Integrated Contigency Plan (ICP). The purpose of the Dyno Nobel - St. Helens Integrated Contingency Plan is to provide guidance to Dyno Nobel Inc. plant personnel for preventing, responding to and minimizing hazards to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, and release of oil or hazardous substances to the air, ground, or surface waters. The plan provides guidance to: assist in the recognition of the release of hazardous materials, provide for notification of internal and external resources for responding to such releases, assist in the assessment of such releases, and provide guidance to initiate mitigation of any releases. This Plan substantially follows the sequence of the National Response Team's (NRT) Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance published in the Federal Register Volume 61, No. 109. The NRT and the agencies responsible for reviewing and approving federal response plans to which the ICP option applies agree that integrated response plans prepared in the format provided in the guidance will be acceptable and be the federally preferred method of response planning. The plan meets the requirements presented in the following regulations:



1. 33 CFR Part 154 (USCG's Facility Response Plan)

2. 29 CFR Part 1910.38(a) (OSHA Emergency Action Plan)

3. 29 CFR Part 1910.119 (OSHA Process Safety Management)

4. 29 CFR Part 1910.120 (OSHA HAZWOPER)

5. 40 CFR Part 68 (EPA Risk Management Program)

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Staffing levels have increased to 75 employees with the addition of key roles in safety. These include an HSE Technician, a Process Safety Management Technician, and an Electrical Engineer. The electrical engineer has been hired to help with the evaluation of a conversion plan for the current Distributed Control System. This evaluation also includes a Level of Protection Analysis that will identify improvements in a new Safety Instrumented System. Each of these computerized systems will be utilized to upgrade the overall safety and reliability of the facility.
